title: Fresh air, new friends, cool tools: Sign up here for a WTA trail-work party
text:
Fresh air, new friends, cool tools: Sign up here for a WTA trail-work party Originally published July 13, 2015 at 6:01 am Updated July 9, 2015 at 1:52 pm Washington Trails Association volunteers work on the Franklin Falls Trail, near Snoqualmie Pass. (Kindra Ramos/WTA photo) Here's a sampling of Washington Trails Association projects for July 16-19 By Brian J. Cantwell Seattle Times outdoors editor 
Hiking among Washington’s mountains, forests and streams is a big benefit of living here. Want to do some payback? Be a trail-work volunteer. Breathe mountain air, meet new friends, and learn to tell a Pulaski from a McLeod (they’re trail tools). 
Here’s a sampling of work parties led by the nonprofit Washington Trails Association this coming week: 
* Independence Lake-North Lake Trail (Darrington Ranger District) In the Verlot area off the Mountain Loop Highway. The trail begins as an easy hike to Independence Lake and then ascends steeply up and over a ridge to remote North Lake. Crew will repair winter damage and improve general condition of the trail. Click to sign up for Thursday, July 16 , or Friday, July 17. 
* Meadow Creek Trail (Skykomish Ranger District) A popular Stevens Pass-Area trail that climbs the first mile through a 1960s burn and salvage clearcut then enters the virgin forest of Henry M. Jackson Wilderness. Crew will focus on maintenance and brush control for first 2 miles of trail. Click to sign up for Friday, July 17 or Saturday, July 18. Most Read Stories 
Icicle Creek Canyon trails (Wenatchee River Ranger District) Icicle Creek Canyon outside of Leavenworth provides access to some of the best backcountry in the state. To the north lies Icicle Ridge and miles of high alpine wandering. Crew will work on several trails in the valley over the course of the weekend. Click to sign up for Friday, July 17 ; Saturday, July 18 ; or Sunday, July 19 . 
White River-area trails, Mount Rainier National Park Help restore the trail leading from White River Campground near the park’s White River Entrance. Crew will get this area ready for the park’s busy summer and may work on annual maintenance of the Wonderland Trail or Glacier Basin Trail. Click to sign up for Friday, July 17 ; Saturday, July 18 ; or Sunday, July 19 . 
More details 
Washington Trails Association hosts more than 750 work parties throughout Washington each year. Volunteers remove downed logs after spring snowmelt, cut away brush, retread worn stretches of trail, and build turnpikes, bridges and drainage structures. No prior experience is necessary, just a desire to work with other outdoors enthusiasts, to have fun playing in the dirt and to contribute to something that benefits all. Tools, hard hats and training provided. You bring lunch, water and work gloves, and work at your own pace. For a full schedule of work parties: www.wta.org/volunteer or call 206-625-1367. *Work parties listed with an asterisk earn credit toward a free Northwest Forest Pass (just two work parties gets you one) or Discover Pass, a $30 value. See website for details. Brian J. Cantwell
